stack.p: Amanda Koon
NUMERACY

A percentage can be viewed as a fraction, ratio or a part of a whole. We can view percentages as a piece of a pie, where the pie is the whole, and the parts of the pie that have unique colors represent parts of the pie. Each of these parts is a percentage of the entire pie. In this module, we will look at what it means for something to be a percentage and show how similar it is to fractions and ratios.
A percent is a fraction that is over 100. $ 1 \% $ can be read as one percent or one per one-hundred.
Note: We can use the $ \% $ symbol to represent percentage but you may also encounter other forms such as $ pct $, or $ pc $
Use the simulator below to see how percentage works on a pie chart. The blue represents your piece of the pie. You can split the pie by using the slider.

column.p: A group of 4 university students start their own social media company called "Link Up" and have great success. The company generates 125.2 million dollars in revenue in its first year. Assuming each student has an equal share in the company, how much does each student make?

stack.name: ans
stack.p: To solve this, we first must determine what percentage of the company each student owns
Since there are 4 students and each student owns an equal piece, the students each of 25% ownership. $ 4 \times 25 \% = 100 \%. $
We can determine the amount of money each student makes by multiplying 25% by the total revenue.
$ 0.25 \times \$ 125.2 $ million $ = \$ 31.3 $ million

button.name: btn1

column.p: What if each student does not make an equal share, and one student in particular had done 70% of the work while the 3 other students did the remaining equally. If the ownership of the company is decided based on work done, how much does each student take home now?

stack.name: ans
stack.p: We know that one student has $ 70 \% $ ownership while the other 3 have $ 30 \% $ put together
This means that the 3 other students each have $ 10 \% $ ownership.
Based on these new percentages, each student makes the following:
Student 1: $ 0.70 \times \$ 125.2 $ million $ = \$ 87.64 $ million
Student 2, 3, 4: $ 0.10 \times \$ 125.2 $ million $ = \$ 12.52 $ million
